title-group.article-title: Two Types of Secret Agency: Conrad, Causation, and Popular Spy Fiction

Mach's Contributions to the Analysis of Sensations in the journal Science credited Mach with an "empirical, phenomenalistic standpoint," while a synoptic essay in The Philosophical Review in 1905 proclaimed that "Mach's concep- tion of philosophy, like Comte's, is positivistic."

Joseph Priestley summed up the independence of the two questions in A Free Discussion of the Doc- trine of Materialism, and Philosophical Necessity (coauthored with Richard Price in 1778): " Whether man be wholly material or not, I apprehend that proof enough is advanced that every human volition is subject to certain fixed laws, and that the pretended self-determining power is altogether imaginary and impossible" (qtd. in Reed 34).
George Combe's Constitution of Man (1827).

Kern points out that popular phrenology long outlived its demise as a scientific theory: "[b]y 1840 phrenology was discredited in scientific circles [but] it continued to influence popular thinking" (229).

Gall's findings is On the Functions of the Brain, pub- lished in four volumes between 1822 and 1826.

Lombroso's thesis of hereditary criminality was a crude marriage of the two theories that I have discussed, evolution and brain localization: "Lombroso har- nessed phrenology, or rather what was now being refined into 'craniometry,' to a specifically evolutionary theory of racial development" (Pick 113).
L'Uomo delinquente (1876)
Crime: Its Causes and Remedies in 1911.
Lombroso's hereditarian model drew criticisms within the criminological community as early as 1885 (139-40)
Kern calls Charles Goring's The English Convict: A Statistical Study (1913) the "scholarly stake in the heart of Lombroso's criminal anthropology" (235).
Jacobs points out that the professor's "large ears, thin like membranes, and standing far out from the sides of his frail skull" (SA 226) mark him as a "Lombrosian type" (82).

Robert Baden-Powell affirmed this narrative of regeneration by espionage in his 1915 memoir: "Spying ... is a great recuperator for the man tired of life" (qtd. in Stafford, The Silent Game 11).
